description: Common K-2 activity type templates with specifications for picture-based, auto-gradable digital learning

drag_drop_sequence.name: Drag and Drop Sequencing
drag_drop_sequence.description: Students drag items into numbered or labeled slots in the correct order

student_actions: View shuffled images/items in a source area
Drag items one at a time to numbered slots (1, 2, 3, etc.)
Rearrange items if needed before submitting
Click 'Check' or 'Submit' button to verify answer
system_responses: Highlight slot when item is being dragged over it
Snap item into slot when released

visual_layout.source_area: Top or left side with randomized items
visual_layout.target_area: Horizontal or vertical slots with clear numbering (1, 2, 3, 4)
visual_layout.slot_visual: Clear border, number visible, drop zone indication

auto_grading.validation: Compare student sequence to correct sequence array
auto_grading.partial_credit_option: Can award partial for mostly correct sequences (G2 only)
auto_grading.feedback_timing: After submission only, not during dragging

typical_use_cases: Daily routine steps (wake up, eat, brush teeth)
Life cycle stages (egg, caterpillar, chrysalis, butterfly)

accessibility_requirements.keyboard_support: Tab to navigate slots, arrow keys to move items, Enter to place
accessibility_requirements.screen_reader: Announce slot numbers, item names, current position
accessibility_requirements.audio: Read prompt and each item name when focused

difficulty_scaling.easier: Fewer items (3), very distinct steps, visual clues (background shading)
difficulty_scaling.harder: More items (5-6), similar-looking steps, less obvious order

sort_categories.name: Sort into Categories
sort_categories.description: Students drag items into 2-4 labeled containers/buckets based on classification rules

student_actions: View items to be sorted in central area
Read or hear category labels
Drag each item to appropriate category container
Submit when all items are sorted
system_responses: Highlight container when item dragged over
Item disappears into container or stays visible inside
Allow moving items between containers before submission

visual_layout.category_containers: 2-4 clearly labeled boxes/buckets at top or sides
visual_layout.item_area: Center or bottom with items to sort
visual_layout.container_labels: Picture + text label for each category
visual_layout.container_size: Large enough to show 2-6 items inside
visual_layout.visual_metaphor: Buckets, boxes, baskets, folders, or bins

auto_grading.validation: All items must be in correct category
auto_grading.all_or_nothing: Yes for K-G1, optional for G2

accessibility_requirements.keyboard_support: Tab between items and containers, Enter to place item in focused container
accessibility_requirements.screen_reader: Announce category names, item count in each, item being moved
accessibility_requirements.audio: Read category labels and item names
accessibility_requirements.color_coding: Use in addition to labels, not as sole differentiator

match_pairs.name: Match Pairs
match_pairs.description: Students connect related items by drawing lines or dragging items to match

student_actions: View two columns of items (left and right)
Click item on left, then matching item on right to draw line
OR drag item from left column onto matching item in right column
Clear incorrect matches if needed
Submit when all pairs matched
system_responses: Draw connecting line between matched items
Highlight paired items in same color
Prevent matching one item to multiple partners
Show count of matched pairs vs. total

visual_layout.layout: Two columns with items to match
visual_layout.column_spacing: Adequate space in middle for visible connection lines
visual_layout.visual_connection: Colored lines or arrows showing matches

auto_grading.validation: All pairs must be correctly matched

typical_use_cases: Match beginning to end of pattern

accessibility_requirements.keyboard_support: Tab to items, arrow keys to navigate, Enter to select, Backspace to clear
accessibility_requirements.screen_reader: Announce item names, matched status, total progress

difficulty_scaling.easier: 3-4 pairs, very obvious matches, distinct images
difficulty_scaling.harder: 5-6 pairs, less obvious relationships, similar images

click_select.name: Click to Select
click_select.description: Students click on all correct items from a set displayed on screen

student_actions: Read/hear prompt asking to find specific items
Click on items that match the criteria
Click again to deselect if needed
Submit when all correct items selected
system_responses: Visual indicator when item selected (checkmark, highlight, border)
Toggle selection on/off with repeated clicks

visual_layout.item_arrangement: Grid layout (2x3, 3x3, etc.) or scattered naturally
visual_layout.correct_items: 2-5 items should be selected (K: 2-3, G1: 3-4, G2: 4-5)
visual_layout.item_size: Large enough for easy clicking (100x100px minimum)

auto_grading.validation: Selected items must exactly match correct set (no extras, none missing)

typical_use_cases: Click pictures showing safe internet use
Click all items used for measurement

accessibility_requirements.keyboard_support: Tab/arrow keys to navigate, Space to toggle selection, Enter to submit
accessibility_requirements.screen_reader: Announce item name, selected status, total selected
accessibility_requirements.audio: Read prompt and each item when focused
accessibility_requirements.visual_feedback: Clear selected state independent of color

difficulty_scaling.easier: Fewer total items (6), obvious correct answers (2-3), clear differences
difficulty_scaling.harder: More items (10-12), more to select (4-5), subtle differences, similar distractors

pattern_complete.name: Complete the Pattern
pattern_complete.description: Students identify and fill in missing elements in visual or logical patterns

student_actions: View pattern with one or more blank spaces
Select correct item from choices to complete pattern
Click or drag item into blank space(s)
Submit answer

visual_layout.pattern_display: Horizontal row or 2D grid showing pattern
visual_layout.blank_indicators: Clear empty boxes or question marks
visual_layout.choice_area: 2-4 possible answers below or to side
visual_layout.pattern_types: AB, ABB, ABC, AAB patterns (K-G1), ABCD or complex patterns (G2)

auto_grading.validation: Selected item(s) must correctly continue or complete pattern
auto_grading.partial_credit_option: For multiple blanks, can award partial (G2)
auto_grading.all_or_nothing: Yes for single blank or K-G1

accessibility_requirements.keyboard_support: Tab to choices, Enter to select, arrow keys to navigate blanks
accessibility_requirements.screen_reader: Announce pattern elements and blank positions
accessibility_requirements.color_independence: Patterns should work in grayscale if possible

difficulty_scaling.easier: Simple AB patterns, 1 blank, obvious continuation
difficulty_scaling.harder: Complex patterns (ABCD), multiple blanks, less obvious rules

hot_spot_click.name: Hot Spot Click
hot_spot_click.description: Students click on specific area(s) of an image to identify locations, objects, or features

student_actions: View large image with prompt
Click on specified item or area in image
May need to find multiple items (click each one)
Submit or auto-advance after all items found
system_responses: Provide audio/visual confirmation when correct area clicked
Show count if multiple items to find

visual_layout.hot_spot_size: Generous click area (80x80px minimum for K)
visual_layout.visual_clarity: Items should be clearly visible, not tiny details
visual_layout.feedback_markers: Checkmarks, circles, or highlights when found

auto_grading.validation: Click must be within defined hot spot boundaries
auto_grading.tolerance: Generous hit boxes for young students
auto_grading.all_or_nothing: Yes for single item or K-G1

typical_use_cases: Find the computer mouse in the classroom
Click all the safety hazards in the picture
Find the input devices on the computer
Click the beginning of the maze
Find all the living things in the scene
Click where the robot should turn
Find examples of patterns in the image

example_skills.title: Click All the Safety Rules Being Followed
Find All Computing Devices in the Library

accessibility_requirements.keyboard_support: Tab to selectable areas, Enter to click
accessibility_requirements.screen_reader: Describe image and announce selectable areas
accessibility_requirements.audio: Read prompt and describe image content
accessibility_requirements.alternative_input: Support for touch and mouse equally

difficulty_scaling.easier: 1 large, obvious item, high contrast, simple scene
difficulty_scaling.harder: Multiple items, busier scene, smaller targets, subtle differences

yes_no_sort.name: Yes/No Binary Sort
yes_no_sort.description: Students sort items into two categories (Yes/No, True/False, Correct/Incorrect, Safe/Unsafe)

student_actions: View item or statement
Drag to Yes or No container (or click Yes/No button)
Continue for all items
Submit when all sorted

visual_layout.categories: Two large, clearly labeled areas (Yes/No, True/False, etc.)
visual_layout.category_visuals: Green checkmark for Yes/True, Red X for No/False (plus text)
visual_layout.items: Presented one at a time OR all visible for sorting
visual_layout.layout_options: Two columns, two buckets, or flip-card style

auto_grading.validation: Each item must be in correct category

typical_use_cases: True or False: This shows kindness
Should you share this information online? (Yes/No)
Does this show good digital citizenship? (Yes/No)

example_skills.title: Is It a Computer? Yes or No
Safe or Unsafe Online? Sort the Behaviors

accessibility_requirements.keyboard_support: Tab to items, arrow keys for Yes/No, Enter to confirm
accessibility_requirements.audio: Read each item and category labels
accessibility_requirements.color_independence: Use checkmark/X icons in addition to color

difficulty_scaling.easier: Obvious answers, fewer items (4-5), clear situations
difficulty_scaling.harder: Nuanced scenarios, more items (7-8), requires thinking

multiple_choice_visual.name: Multiple Choice (Visual)
multiple_choice_visual.description: Students choose the correct picture from 3-4 visual options in response to a question

student_actions: Read/hear question or prompt
View 3-4 picture options
Click on correct picture
Submit answer
system_responses: Show correct answer if incorrect (after attempts)

visual_layout.question_area: Top of screen with text and audio button
visual_layout.selection_indicator: Border highlight or checkmark on selected option

auto_grading.validation: Selected option must match correct answer

typical_use_cases: What comes next in the pattern?
Which picture shows the rule being followed?
What should the robot do next?
Which tool would you use for this job?
Which picture shows the correct sequence?

example_skills.title: What Comes Next in This Pattern?

accessibility_requirements.keyboard_support: Arrow keys to navigate options, Enter to select
accessibility_requirements.screen_reader: Read question and describe each option
accessibility_requirements.visual_clarity: High contrast options with clear differences

difficulty_scaling.easier: 3 options, very different images, obvious correct answer
difficulty_scaling.harder: 4 options, similar images, requires careful analysis

counting_interaction.name: Counting and Number Recognition
counting_interaction.description: Students count items, select quantities, or match numbers to sets

student_actions: View set of objects or pictures
Count items (may click each to count)
Select number OR drag number to match set
Submit answer
system_responses: Items may light up when clicked for counting

visual_layout.counting_support: Items arranged in rows of 5 or familiar patterns

auto_grading.validation: Selected number must match item count

typical_use_cases: How many robots do you see?
Count the inputs on the computer
How many steps in the algorithm?
Match the number to the set
Count the loops in the pattern
How many items did we sort?

example_skills.title: How Many Steps in the Algorithm?

accessibility_requirements.keyboard_support: Tab to items and numbers, Enter to select
accessibility_requirements.visual_support: Group items in familiar patterns (dice, dominoes)

difficulty_scaling.easier: 1-5 items, arranged in familiar patterns, clear spacing
difficulty_scaling.harder: 6-12 items, random arrangement, overlapping, similar items

path_tracing.name: Path Tracing and Navigation
path_tracing.description: Students trace or click along a path, make directional choices, or guide a character through a route

student_actions: View start and end points on map/grid
Click squares to create path OR drag finger to trace
OR click directional arrows to guide character
Submit or auto-check when path complete
system_responses: Highlight path as student creates it

visual_layout.character: Friendly character to guide (robot, animal, person)

auto_grading.validation: Path must reach goal, may need to match specific route or just any valid route
auto_grading.partial_credit_option: No for K-G1, possibly yes for G2

typical_use_cases: Help the robot reach the charging station
Trace the path from home to school
Guide the animal to its food

example_skills.title: Guide the Bunny to the Carrots

accessibility_requirements.keyboard_support: Arrow keys to move character, Enter to confirm step
accessibility_requirements.visual_path: Clear visual trail showing path taken

difficulty_scaling.easier: Smaller grid, no obstacles, clear straight path
difficulty_scaling.harder: Larger grid, multiple obstacles, requires planning, specific route required

general_principles: All activities must work on touch screens (tablets) and with mouse input
Large, clear touch targets (minimum 44px, recommend 60px for K)
Immediate visual feedback for all interactions
Audio support for all text instructions
Generous error tolerance (e.g., wide hit boxes, forgiving timing)
Prevent accidental submissions (confirmation or clear submit button)
Consistent UI patterns across all activity types
Celebratory feedback for correct answers (stars, confetti, sounds)
Encouraging feedback for incorrect attempts (no negative language)
technical_requirements: HTML5 Canvas or SVG for graphics
Drag-drop using touch-friendly libraries (e.g., interact.js, SortableJS)
Text-to-speech API for audio (Web Speech API or service)
Works on iPad Safari, Chrome, Edge browsers
Responsive design for different screen sizes
Offline capability desirable for classroom use
data_tracking: Log incorrect answers for teacher review
